p: The combination of a hydrothermal and microwave-assisted synthetic procedure is capable of reducing the growth temperature and time and as a consequence the consumption of electricity and the overall costs of chemical synthesis [ 34]. Considering the growth of materials in short time intervals and the higher product yield as compared with the conventional synthetic methods, this technique is indeed environmentally friendly [ 35]. Nevertheless, it is difficult to control the particle size, purity, and morphology of material at large scale (i.e., larger equipment and solvent amounts are required).
